17.84.text: It features some of the most dramatic

23.36.text: mountain scenery in the whole of England.

28.56.text: It's just over six miles from Skelwith Bridge

31.84.text: to the head of the valley.

38.38.text: We're off on a superb low level walk

53.14.text: then back along the valley floor.

57.32.text: The walk is just under six miles in total

61.78.text: and features some of the finest

63.84.text: low level views in the whole of the Lake District.

69.86.text: As well as some of the quirkiest signs!

80.06.text: The scenery is spectacular from the start

88.77.text: But there's much more to the Langdale Valley than superb views.

98.18.text: This has been a working landscape for at least the last 4,000 years.

104.28.text: It's not known when human habitation began

110.62.text: Neolithic craftsmen were at work on the slopes of Pike O'Stickle.

118.74.text: Using it to manufacture large quantities of fine stone axes.

123.34.text: Which were then traded throughout the whole of Britain.

127.72.text: Of course, back then the valley floor would have been tree covered.

133.92.text: It was the Norse Settlers to this land

136.83.text: who cleared the trees and introduced livestock.

149.72.text: It means, quite simply, Long Valley

158.44.text: The first part of this walk follows a short section of the Cumbria Way.

170.38.text: We're following it for just over a mile.

174.06.text: But when we get to the barn at Oak Howe

177.04.text: we turn right and head into the trees.

181.96.text: And now we are firmly in gunpowder country.

191.80.text: the major industries around here were farming

200.53.text: And to extract the slate from these hills

211.01.text: a gunpowder factory was established at Elterwater.

216.20.text: Powered by water from Great Langdale Beck

221.22.text: it used charcoal made in these woods

225.14.text: and mixed with imported saltpetre and sulphur

229.19.text: to produce high grade course black gunpowder for the quarrying industry.

243.88.text: Of course, there still is a quarry here at Elterwater.

248.56.text: But nowadays the main industry is tourism.

254.00.text: Many of the former quarry workers cottages

262.86.text: a modern timeshare and hotel development.

268.82.text: The village takes its name from Elter water

272.88.text: The small lake to the east.

278.94.text: means the Lake of the Swans.

287.66.text: For the return leg of the walk we take this access road to the quarries.

294.83.text: Just before we get to the quarries, we take this path to the right.

301.29.text: to walk alongside the river, to the village of Chapel Stile.

326.78.text: is named after the celebrated walking guide author

333.59.text: But it actually refers to the village Wainwright.

337.16.text: A wain was a small farm cart.

341.06.text: The village Wainwright made and repaired them.

346.73.text: We're going to turn left just before this school sign.

350.33.text: But first, I've got a bit of shopping to do.

358.84.text: so I'm going to apply to become a customer.

365.02.text: Right. I've shopped until I've dropped.

377.80.text: Maybe next time. I've just had an ice cream.

393.19.text: We're coming to my favourite bit of the walk now.

401.29.text: There's quite a lot of evidence of the old disused quarries around here.

406.35.text: There's a number of old spoil heaps on the fells to our left.

421.62.text: I'm afraid you're going to have to get used to that view.

425.30.text: Because it is going to be with us

432.50.text: That's Harrison Stickle in the middle

437.46.text: The dark looking cliff face to the right is Pavey Ark.

445.52.text: And Pike O'Stickle to the left.

458.12.text: A sign on the last kissing gate before we cross the river.

461.23.text: A very worthy cause, the air ambulance.

463.87.text: You never know when you might need one.

469.64.text: we are going to go right.

471.22.text: over that footbridge there to cross the river

492.46.text: it took you up to the road, and you then had

496.00.text: about 50 or 60 yards on the road to walk.

498.76.text: Which is fine, because it is not a busy road,

501.72.text: but to be honest you'd prefer not to walk on the road

505.38.text: and I've had one or two near misses there with cars coming around a blind corner.

514.26.text: I'll just show you if I turn the camera.

520.76.text: There you are. New path, all the way down to the end of the walk.

533.92.text: We're on the final half mile.

537.11.text: Nice bit of sunshine on Harrison Stickle and Loft Crag there.

542.18.text: It really has been a super walk.

548.37.text: And we've even got time for a spot of refreshment before we head back home.
